natural problem: Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$?
natural solution: The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.

Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}

\angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;

A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));

label("$A$",A,S); label("$B$",B,SE); label("$C$",C,NE); label("$D$",D,N); label("$E$",EE,N); label("$F$",F,W); label("$G$",G,W); label("$H$",H,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy] Note that we also could have solved this problem by noticing that $\overline{FC}\parallel\overline{HA}$, so $\angle APD = \angle FCD$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AH CD :: "real * real" and P :: "real * real" and angle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "regular_octagon AH CD P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));
 label("$A$",A,S); label("$B$",B,SE); label("$C$",C,NE); label("$D$",D,N); label("$E$",EE,N); label("$F$",F,W); label("$G$",G,W); label("$H$",H,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy] Note that we also could have solved this problem by noticing that $\overline{FC}\parallel\overline{HA}$, so $\angle APD = \angle FCD$.
 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AH CD :: "real * real" and P :: "real * real" and angle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "regular_octagon AH CD P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a regular octagon AH CD P, what is the measure of the angle at point P? The final answer is 45 degrees.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: "real*real"
and AH CD :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and angle :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_octagon A B C D E F G H"
and h1 : "intersect_at AH CD P"
shows  "angle A H P = 45"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));
 label("$A$",A,S); label("$B$",B,SE); label("$C$",C,NE); label("$D$",D,N); label("$E$",EE,N); label("$F$",F,W); label("$G$",G,W); label("$H$",H,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy] Note that we also could have solved this problem by noticing that $\overline{FC}\parallel\overline{HA}$, so $\angle APD = \angle FCD$.
 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: "real*real"
and AH CD :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and angle :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_octagon A B C D E F G H"
and h1 : "intersect_at AH CD P"
shows  "angle A H P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given an octagon defined by points A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H and two lines AH and CD that intersect at point P, prove that the angle at AHP equals 45 degrees.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: angle and B :: angle and C :: angle and P :: angle
assumes h0 : "A = B"
and h1 : "B = C"
and h2 : "A + B + C = P"
and h3 : "regular_octagon ABCDEFGH"
shows  "P = 45"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));
 label("$A$",A,S); label("$B$",B,SE); label("$C$",C,NE); label("$D$",D,N); label("$E$",EE,N); label("$F$",F,W); label("$G$",G,W); label("$H$",H,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy] Note that we also could have solved this problem by noticing that $\overline{FC}\parallel\overline{HA}$, so $\angle APD = \angle FCD$.
 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: angle and B :: angle and C :: angle and P :: angle
assumes h0 : "A = B"
and h1 : "B = C"
and h2 : "A + B + C = P"
and h3 : "regular_octagon ABCDEFGH"
shows  "P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given an octagon ABCDEFGH where A = B = C, and the sum of angles A, B and C is denoted by P. If this octagon is regular (all sides are equal and all angles are equal), find the value of P. The final answer is 45 degrees.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AH CD P :: real
assumes h0 : "AH = CD"
and h1 : "P = AH + CD"
and h2 : "AH = 45"
shows  "P = 45"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));

 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AH CD P :: real
assumes h0 : "AH = CD"
and h1 : "P = AH + CD"
and h2 : "AH = 45"
shows  "P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given that the lengths of line segments AH and CD are equal, and that P is the sum of the lengths of AH and CD. If AH is 45 units long, find the length of P. The final answer is 45 units.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "regular_octagon ABCDEFGH"
and h1 : "extend AH to P"
and h2 : "extend CD to P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));

 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "regular_octagon ABCDEFGH"
and h1 : "extend AH to P"
and h2 : "extend CD to P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If ABCDEFGH is a regular octagon and AH and CD are extended to meet at point P, then the angle at P is 45 degrees.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: point
and AH CD :: "point => point => real"
and ABCDEFGH :: "point list"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_octagon ABCDEFGH"
and h1 : "AH A H = CD C D"
and h2 : "extended AH A H P"
and h3 : "extended CD C D P"
shows  "angle A P H = 45"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));
 label("$A$",A,S); label("$B$",B,SE); label("$C$",C,NE); label("$D$",D,N); label("$E$",EE,N); label("$F$",F,W); label("$G$",G,W); label("$H$",H,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy] Note that we also could have solved this problem by noticing that $\overline{FC}\parallel\overline{HA}$, so $\angle APD = \angle FCD$.
 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: point
and AH CD :: "point => point => real"
and ABCDEFGH :: "point list"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_octagon ABCDEFGH"
and h1 : "AH A H = CD C D"
and h2 : "extended AH A H P"
and h3 : "extended CD C D P"
shows  "angle A P H = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a regular octagon ABCDEFGH, and two lines AH and CD, where AH is the line segment from point A to point H and CD is the line segment from point C to point D. The length of AH is equal to the length of CD. Point P is on the extension of both lines AH and CD. What is the measure of angle APH? The final answer is 45 degrees.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AH CD :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and P :: real
assumes h0 : "is_regular_octagon A B C D E F G H"
and h1 : "intersect_at AH CD P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));

 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AH CD :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and P :: real
assumes h0 : "is_regular_octagon A B C D E F G H"
and h1 : "intersect_at AH CD P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a regular octagon ABCDEFGH, where lines AH and CD intersect at point P, find the measure of angle P. The final answer is 45 degrees.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AH CD P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "regular_octagon AH CD"

shows  "angle P = 45"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.

 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));

 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AH CD P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "regular_octagon AH CD"
and h1 : "extended_to_meet AH CD P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a regular octagon with sides AH and CD, if they are extended to meet at point P, then the angle at P is 45 degrees.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_octagon A B C D E F G H"
and h1 : "is_extended_to_meet_at A H C D P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}

 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));

 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_regular_octagon A B C D E F G H"
and h1 : "is_extended_to_meet_at A H C D P"
shows  "angle P = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a regular octagon defined by the vertices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H. If an extension is drawn from vertices A, H to meet at point P with the line CD, find the measure of angle P. The final answer is 45 degrees.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: point
and AH CD :: line
and ABCDEFGH :: polygon
assumes h0 : "regular ABCDEFGH"
and h1 : "AH = join A H"
and h2 : "CD = join C D"
and h3 : "intersects_at AH CD P"
shows  "angle A P C = 45"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Sides $\overline{AH}$ and $\overline{CD}$ of regular octagon $ABCDEFGH$ are extended to meet at point $P$. What is the degree measure of angle $P$? The final Answer is 45^\circ
 ### Proof
 The sum of the angle measures of an octagon is $180(8-2) = 1080$ degrees, so each angle of a regular octagon measures $1080^\circ/8=135^\circ$.
 Therefore, $\angle BCD= 135^\circ$, which means $\angle BCP = 180^\circ - \angle BCD = 45^\circ$.
 Similarly, $\angle PAB = 45^\circ$. Since $\angle ABC = 135^\circ$, the reflex angle at $B$ that is an interior angle of $ABCP$ has measure $360^\circ - 135^\circ = 225^\circ$. The interior angles of quadrilateral $ABCP$ must sum to $360^\circ$, so we have  \begin{align}
 \angle P &= 360^\circ - \angle PAB - (\text{reflex }\angle B) - \angle BCP\\ &=360^\circ - 45^\circ - 225^\circ - 45^\circ = \boxed{45^\circ}. \end{align} [asy] unitsize(0.6inch); pair A,B,C,D,EE,F,G,H,P;
 A = rotate(-67.5)*(1,0); B = rotate(45)*A; C=rotate(45)*B; D = rotate(45)*C; EE = rotate(45)*D; F = rotate(45)*EE; G = rotate(45)*F; H = rotate(45)*G; P = A + (rotate(-90)*(D-A)); draw (A--B--C--D--EE--F--G--H--A--P--C,linewidth(1));
 label("$A$",A,S); label("$B$",B,SE); label("$C$",C,NE); label("$D$",D,N); label("$E$",EE,N); label("$F$",F,W); label("$G$",G,W); label("$H$",H,S); label("$P$",P,S); [/asy] Note that we also could have solved this problem by noticing that $\overline{FC}\parallel\overline{HA}$, so $\angle APD = \angle FCD$.
 Since $\overline{CF}\parallel\overline {ED}$, we have $\angle FCD = 180^\circ - \angle CDE = 180^\circ - 135^\circ = 45^\circ$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E F G H P :: point
and AH CD :: line
and ABCDEFGH :: polygon
assumes h0 : "regular ABCDEFGH"
and h1 : "AH = join A H"
and h2 : "CD = join C D"
and h3 : "intersects_at AH CD P"
shows  "angle A P C = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a regular polygon ABCDEFGH, lines AH and CD intersect at point P. Find the measure of angle APC. The final answer is 45 degrees.
